definition: **noun / hi-fi accessory.** An **outboard electronic speed-controller** for AC-motor belt-drive turntables, enabling precise 33⅓/45 RPM switching and fine-tuning of platter speed. Introduced in the 1970s alongside high-end turntable designs, speed-boxes address inherent AC motor limitations by regulating frequency and voltage externally rather than through built-in circuitry. Early models like the Thorens TP-60 and later audiophile units from Clearaudio, Origin Live, and Walker Audio provide electronic speed switching, eliminating manual belt repositioning, while offering fine adjustment typically within ±3-5% to compensate for voltage fluctuations, belt stretch, or off-pitch recordings. Higher-end controllers incorporate quartz-locked precision, reducing wow and flutter to near-DC motor levels at a fraction of the cost. The speed-box became essential for DJs requiring instant 33/45 switching and audiophiles pursuing reference-level accuracy from vintage belt-drive decks. Modern implementations often include digital displays, strobe calibration functions, and motor start/stop control. Particularly valued in the used market for upgrading classic turntables like Linn Sondek LP12, Thorens TD-160, or Rega Planar models, transforming basic AC-synchronous designs into precision playback instruments. Prices range from $200 for basic units to $2,000+ for laboratory-grade controllers.
etymology: Coined in the 1970s hi-fi industry, combining "speed" (rotational velocity) with "box" (outboard electronics housing), paralleling terminology like "phono box" for external preamps.
